newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan PM gets royal support for economic reform.
newsitem.headline: Jordan PM gets royal support for economic reform.

text.p: King Hussein of Jordan has indicated he is ready to give Prime Minister Abdul-Karim al-Kabariti a longterm mandate for wide-ranging economic and administrative reforms, the official Petra news agency said.
It quoted the king, who has reshuffled prime ministers on a regular basis, as telling Jordan television late on Friday he spoke to Kabariti recently about the challenges facing Jordan.

"I said to him if he still had the same enthusiasm, honesty, bravery, integrity and righteousness which we know he has ... we will look at future issues with a new style," Petra quoted King Hussein as saying.
"But if he is scared of confronting storms...and I do not think that is the case, then we will have to think of another solution," he added.
Since his appointment one year ago Kabariti has pushed ahead with IMF-backed economic reforms including a cut in bread subsidies which led to riots in southern Jordan last August.

Jordan is due to hold parliamentary elections by November this year. The king had been expected to announce a new interim government within weeks because under Jordanian law, ministers serving in cabinet cannot stand for a parliamentary seat.
At present around two thirds of the cabinet are members of parliament and would have to step down before the elections if they want to run again for parliament.
But King Hussein said his discussions with Kabariti had gone further than discussing the interim period leading up to the elections, which should be held by November.
"The next stage will not only be an interim phase for holding the elections," he said.
The king said in future parliamentarians may be kept out of the cabinet, splitting the government's legislative and executive branches.

"Plenty of evidence shows that it is not right to combine deputies and ministers (roles)," he said. "The deputy is a monitor of the government and he should devote his time and effort to following up the different laws put before them."

Critics of the present system say it almost guarantees the government a majority in the 80-seat lower house of parliament because a quarter of deputies are also ministers. Other deputies support the government in the hope of winning a cabinet post at the next reshuffle, they say.

King Hussein said Jordan faced a battle against "deadly bureaucracy". After visiting a government department with Kabariti recently ... "we left with the impression that this department would have been more productive if 70 percent of it were cut back," he said.
He also criticised Islamist MPs who walked out of parliament last week in protest at what they said was a weak government reaction to Israeli plans to build Jewish settlements in Arab East Jerusalem.
"I don't think that deputies were elected just to withdraw from parliament every now and then," he said.
